types.text: Before children begin to speak, they show signs of understanding language by responding to familiar words and phrases. Below are some common examples. Does your child do any of these?
types.title: First signs of understanding

types.text: In the list below, please mark the phrases that your child seems to understand
types.title: Phrases

types.text: The following is a list of typical words in young children's vocabularies. For words your child UNDERSTANDS but does not yet say, choose the option "understands". For words that your child both understands and also SAYS, choose the option "understands and says". You only need to choose one option. If your child uses a different pronunciation of a word (for example, "raffe" for "giraffe" or "sketti" for "spagetti") or knows a different word that has a similar meaning as the word listed here (e.g., "nana" for "grandma"), go ahead and mark it.  Remember, this is a "catalogue" of words that are used by many different children. Don't worry if your child knows only a few right now.
types.title: Vocabulary checklist

sections.text: When infants are learning to communicate, they often use gestures to make their wishes known. For each item below, choose the option that describes your child's actions right now.
sections.title: First communicative gestures

sections.text: Does your child do any of the following?
sections.title: Games and routines

sections.text: Does your child do or try to do any of the following?
sections.title: Actions with objects

sections.text: Here are some things that young children sometimes do with stuffed animals or dolls. Please select the actions that you have seen your child do.
sections.title: Pretending to be a parent

sections.text: Does your child do or try to do any of the following?
sections.title: Imitating other adult actions (using real or toy implements)
